info.subTitle: I enjoy defining problems and finding solutions to make the world a bit more convenient.

leftFirstContent: I wasn't initially interested in development. Just two years ago, I didn’t even know what coding was, but as I became more interested in the world, I realized how many inconveniences existed.
Through this process, I realized the importance of problem-defining skills and became interested in the technologies that could solve these issues.

s a result, I discovered 42 Seoul, a school that offered project-based active learning of fundamental computer science concepts such as operating systems, data structures, algorithms, and networks, rather than just lecture-based learning.
After completing two years of study there, I'm now pursuing a career as a developer with a focus on front-end development.
leftSecondContent: I appreciate beauty, which is why I always consider whether my code is understandable to someone seeing it for the first time and whether its structure is overly complex.
While optimization is another matter, I don't believe that more complex code necessarily equates to better performance.
I think that teamwork surpasses individual effort, which is why I consider communication skills essential for developers.
Having started from scratch, I enjoy and excel at explaining concepts in a way that anyone can understand.
rightFirstContent: I'm curious about many things and eager to learn more. As I go through life, I realize there's always more that I don't know than what I do know.
This awareness keeps me humble, acknowledging that I can always be wrong, and motivates me to continually strive for growth.
I believe that while things can be difficult, nothing is impossible. Having started in a completely new field two years ago, I had no choice but to work harder than others.
I tackled each problem as it arose, gaining experience through over 300 code reviews and writing more than 10,000 lines of code for a single project.
As a result, I've become fearless in acquiring new knowledge and skills and facing challenges.
rightSecondContent: I believe that knowledge broadens our perspective, and our perspective shapes our dreams. That's why I love learning, challenging myself, and documenting my experiences.
I read books because I want to know and see more. I enjoy challenges, so I often just dive in and try things. Recently, I went on a trek in the Himalayas.
I believe that what we learn becomes truly ours when we record and share it. That's why I run a small YouTube channel, like a growing diary where I jot down my thoughts and experiences.

education.secondContent: B.A. degree expected in Computer Science in 2028

language.title: Language
language.skills: C/C++, JavaScript, TypeScript, HTML, CSS, English

details.description: Multi-process, multi-threading, OOP, experience with memory management in various toy projects.
Experience developing SPAs with Vanilla JavaScript.
Experience using interfaces for type settings in React.
Able to build pages using HTML.
Able to design layouts using CSS.
OPIc AL, able to communicate fluently with native speakers, and comfortable reading English documentation.

frontend.title: Frontend
frontend.skills: React, Next.js, React Query, Redux, TailwindCSS, Framer Motion, i18n

details.description: Capable of developing routes and components using React-dom.
Experience developing routes using dynamic routing and middleware.
Experience in API caching and implementing infinite scroll.
Experience managing global state for dark mode and book information.
Capable of designing and customizing components with Tailwind CSS.
Able to implement simple animation effects.
Experience implementing bilingual (Korean/English) features using i18n.

tools.title: Etc
tools.skills: Git/GitHub, Figma, Slack, Notion, Visual Studio Code, Docker

details.description: Familiar with issue tracking and branch strategy in Git, and capable of team collaboration.
Skilled in building design systems and creating prototypes.
Excellent communication in team settings, always available.
Highly proficient in organizing information and managing team workspaces with Notion.
Uses Vim plugins within Visual Studio Code.
Able to build Docker images and set up Docker environments.

overview.techKeywords: C++98, Makefile, HTML, CSS, OOP, Non-block I/O, I/O Multiplexing (kqueue), HTTP/1.1
overview: Webserv is an ambitious project undertaken as part of the School 42 curriculum, challenging students to develop a robust HTTP/1.1 compatible web server in C++ 98.
This project pushes the boundaries of low-level network programming, requiring the implementation of non-blocking I/O operations and efficient request handling.

Key features include the use of I/O multiplexing with `poll()` (or equivalent), ensuring the server never blocks or hangs indefinitely, and the ability to serve static websites while supporting multiple HTTP methods.By implementing these advanced concepts, Webserv not only serves as a practical learning tool for understanding web server architecture but also demonstrates the power and flexibility of C++ in creating high-performance network applications. The successful completion of this project showcases a deep understanding of network protocols, system-level programming, and efficient resource management in a challenging, real-world scenario.

highlights.title: HIGHLIGHTS
highlights.highlights: A high-performance HTTP/1.1 server implementation in C++98, featuring non-blocking I/O and advanced request handling capabilities for efficient web serving.
